title: Thursday, 15th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Thursday then. Markets Live. Let's do this, I guess.

BE11:03am

https://twitter.com/TonyTassell/status/875005702988853252

BE11:04am

On the right is Tony Tassell, our Deputy News Editor and the steady hand on the tiller each day.

11:03 am
BE11:04am

On the left is Geoff Ho. The Sunday Express's business editor.

BE11:04am

Geoff and Tony are pictured outside the Southwark Tavern, very shortly after one of them was discharged from Royal London Hospital

BE11:04am

Where he'd been for more than a week, having been stabbed in the neck after facing off with some terrorists outside the self-same Southwark Tavern.

11:04 am
BE11:05am

If you want to read more about Geoff, try here: http://www.mirror....ch-heroic-10557375

BE11:05am

And if you want to read more about Tony, I really can't help you.

undefined
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Did I say right? I meant left to the viewer.

BE11:06am

Sheesh. Apologies, I'm not 100% switched on this morning.

BE11:06am

Which is fine because neither is the market.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

FTSE off 0.8% at pixel.

BE11:07am

Post the Fed rate hike everyone had already priced in.

BE11:07am

And the pre-announcement of a normalisation of the Fed balance sheet later this year that everyone hadn't.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

Worry here is that the Fed has set its course and will stick to it irrespective of what's happening, right?

BE11:08am

I'm not a Fed watcher, I dunno about this stuff.

BE11:08am

SocGen are Fedwatchers. Have them instead.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

The FOMC raised rates by 25bp, maintained a projection that suggests a further rate hike this year, while the infamous dot-lot looks for a 2.9% Funds rate a the end of 2019, and a 3% rate ‘in the long-term. Inflation forecasts for 2017 were cut and GDP forecasts were nudged up. Recent soft inflation was described as being transitory and more detail emerged of the plan to run down the Fed’s balance sheet. The short version of that is that they may start this autumn, and they will move slowly – so slowly that the balance sheet will surely still be huge when the next recession comes along.

BE11:09am

Cue a debate about whether this was a hawkish move, given the absence of inflation. Surely we would have been extremely critical if they had left rates on hold when it was Fed communication more than anything else that persuaded the markets to price a move in with so much confidence. The Fed only wants to move when doing so is discounted by markets, so they have delivered this one despite the soft CPI print. But crucially, the tone of the discussion in the press conference about neutral rates still reflects huge uncertainty and concern about how low they are. The median long-term dot in the Fed Funds dotplot may be at 3% but Janet Yellen doesn’t sound as confident of when ‘neutral’ is as is about the probability of hitting the inflation target.

BE11:09am

All of this leaves rates trundling slowly higher and bond yields firmly in a range. 10year TIPS yields are at 42bp this morning, 1bp below their 2017 average, just below the mid-point o their 30-60bp range. That level makes USD/JPY look a bit low to me and as markets calm down, the yen should weaken again. EUR/JPY remains a very attractive buy here. But the big market driver may be less where TIPS go (nowhere) than where yields go elsewhere. Real 10year Bund yields are at -93bp, well above 2017 average levels. And low enough they have plenty of upside, which should underpin the Euro. For now, EUR/USD seems to have a hard ceiling at 1.13, but if we see positions lighten up somewhat while meandering in the current mini-range (1.1150-1.13?) then we will make a base from which to push higher.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

And Exane.

BE11:09am

Janet Yellen was under pressure to justify the Fed’s move despite declining inflation, flattening
yield curve and uncertainty regarding the neutral Fed Funds rate. In the short run, the Fed is
probably not making a mistake as financial conditions remain extremely supportive for growth and
the global economy is in good shape. That said, we doubt the Fed will be able to raise the Fed
Funds rate to 3% as planned given the low inflation regime.

BE11:09am

We maintain our view that the Fed will be more hawkish than the market currently expects. This
means another rate hike this year and the start of the balance sheet reduction. Ten-year bond
yields have some upside from here as they are currently below our estimated fair value of 2.4%.
The USD should also be mildly firmer in H2.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

And Stifel.

BE11:11am

Every Fed Chairman since W.W. II has exited the office while tightening monetary policy, thus bequeathing to their successor the optionality to tighten or loosen. This Fed is no different. We doubt the Fed can exceed 1.75-2.00% fed funds this cycle (1.16% after today’s hike) until 1Q18, with a recession following perhaps 15 months later. As a result, we think the S&P 500 tops 2H18E (up mid-teens percent from YE 2016 2,239 or to the mid-2,500s and perhaps a bit more), whereupon we think the S&P 500 falls 28% peak-to-trough 2H18 to 2019, mostly in 2019. Upside also appears capped by a rising discount rate applied to EPS (if reflation/Fed exit is facilitated) and lagging growth abroad, as well as deflationary pressures (wages, oil) and political delays with fiscal assistance (beyond simple tax cuts in 2018E). To gauge the risk of “Fed policy mistake” we will watch the yield curve, especially the 10Y for upside break-out. As for Fed balance sheet unwind, we continue to believe the U.S. 10Y yield won’t exceed 4% through the late 2020s, which supports the S&P 500 P/E ratio. Nonetheless, with Growth expensive and credit, capex and positive pricing power all late cycle following a balance sheet recession, we prefer the Reflation Trade to the top, followed by bond proxies and purely defensive growth in the bear market of 2019.

BE11:11am

It's a long note, this one, from Stifel's Barry Bannister.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

I'll cut to the last par.

BE11:12am

Some analysts at the Fed’s press conference criticized the way in which the Fed is opportunistic and learning as it goes along, but we have more sympathy. With no Fed having experienced an environment similar to this one since the 1930s-40s (and all of those people are dead), we have more simpatico for Yellen & Co. By way of background, we have believed for some time that the U.S. for the past decade (or longer) has been experiencing a balance sheet recession (excess debt, over-capacity, lack of pricing power). By definition, that means new credit, more capex and positive pricing power are in short supply and thus de facto late cycle (or “recovery” has been a mirage). As a result, if the equities of those companies that provide credit (Financials), capex (a handful of Industrials) and are pricing power beneficiaries (some Materials, Energy stocks) outperform, that would be our “tell” that investors are finally over-confident with respect to recovery/normalcy, which we expect by mid-2018. While low rates as stated above may persist to the year 2028 and a desire for growth in a deflationary environment make “FAANG stocks” desirable to some, we question the predictability of long-term cash flow streams in the Tech industry (which embodies the notion of creative destruction) and thus abhor high P/E ratios in Tech, generally. For their part, we believe the time to buy bond proxies and purely defensive growth, which we call the “Deflation Trade” (which is the diametrical opposite of the Reflation Trade), will be after the S&P 500 tops and during the bear market of 2019E. For now, we favor the Reflation Trade to the top, and follow the maxim of “Jack be nimble, Jack be quick.”

undefined
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Purplebricks mentioned ..............

Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 376.25, down 23.75 (-5.94%), High: 394.00, Low: 366.50, Volume: 796.97k
BE11:13am

It's a difficult stock to write about for many, many reasons.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

For one, there's an army of retailers who take a near-obsessive interest in it. And (pace GKP) we know how that can play out.

BE11:15am

Anyway, the stock started sliding yesterday post Lex doing a Lex.

BE11:15am

https://www.ft.com...-a1f2-db19572361bb

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Whose caution is elegantly phrased, though shouldn't really come as news to any holders.

BE11:18am

Beyond that, I'd point you towards the increased levels of uncertainty about transaction volumes around Brexit and so on. That's a bug that's in a lot of stocks right now.

Foxtons Group PLC (FOXT:LSE): Last: 99.50, down 1 (-1.00%), High: 103.00, Low: 99.50, Volume: 93.91k
11:18 am
Countrywide PLC (CWD:LSE): Last: 152.08, down 3.92 (-2.52%), High: 155.00, Low: 151.25, Volume: 63.99k
BE11:19am

(@Stephen P: I've a solution to that. Can you guess what it is?)

BE11:19am

No particular news in the name beyond that.

11:19 am
undefined
BE11:20am

Down to three FTSE 100 risers now. Feels a bit fragile out there.

BE11:21am

The DFS warning has been mentioned on the right already.

11:20 am
DFS Furniture PLC (DFS:LSE): Last: 199.00, down 53 (-21.03%), High: 212.00, Low: 190.00, Volume: 3.26m
BE11:22am

Confirmation that big-ticket sales are slowing

BE11:23am

There's been some interesting stuff written in recent weeks about retailers hedging FX into Brexit, which kept consumer spending relatively insulated because costs weren't being passed on.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

BUt now the hedges are rolling off and you get what looks like a delayed response, which certainly seems to chime with the inflation and wage growth figures we've been seeing lately..

BE11:25am

Though there's the counter argument that DFS isn't a very good business, and was gutted by PE then floated on puffy expectations.

BE11:25am

Perhaps both can be true. Here's Jefferies.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

A slowdown in trading in the past 3-4 months has led DFS to reduce FY17E EBITDA guidance by c.12%, implying FY17E PBT/EPS cuts of c.17%. DFS believes that LFL sales could recover, however, we take a more cautious view given rising inflation and Brexit uncertainty. We cut our FY18E EBITDA by 9% and FY18E PBT/EPS by 14%. Thus with the stock trading on 12.0x our new cal 18 EPS we downgrade to Hold with a lowered PT of 210p (10x).

BE11:25am

[I]ndustry sofa sales have been weak for a few months with the BRC-KPMG Retail Sales Monitor commenting in May that "sofas didn't fare so well" as furniture sales declined. DFS estimate that industry sofa sales fell c.5%-6% Feb-May, as have DFS' LFL sales (from +c.4% in 1H17).

BE11:26am

Sales could recover but consumer confidence under threat. DFS is quite used to volatile trading hence why they don't like commenting on just a few months' trading. However, with less than 2 months to go DFS has lowered FY17E EBITDA guidance to £82-87m, the midpoint of which is 11.5% below consensus expectations (£95.5m). Looking ahead, DFS believes its possible sales will recover on a 12-15 month view and thus con est for FY18E EBITDA of £99m could still be achievable (assuming consumer confidence does not deteriorate further). Given our UK survey results ("Consumers Still Hoping For The Best") we believe rising inflation in cal 2H17 could still knock confidence and that Brexit uncertainty could weigh, along with medium-term threats to employment from automation. Hence, we take a more cautious view on sofa sales improving in FY18E.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

FY17E EPS cut 17% to 20p, FY18E EPS cut 14% to 21.2p; Hold. Being prudent we keep our -2% FY18E LFL sales est despite the now easier comp in the 2H. We do give DFS credit for gross margins improving c.25bps after being worse than anticipated in FY17E (JEFe -75bps) but overall we see EBITDA recovering from c.£85m to c.£89m (was £98m). Longer term we expect DFS to win share but we expect distributable cashflow to fall to £41m in FY17E and c.£48m in FY18E. We believe DFS can continue to pay special dividends but at a lower rate hence we downgrade to Hold.

BE11:27am

And a bit from Stifel.

BE11:27am

DFS sales have historically been volatile around pre-election periods. This has been compounded by the later Easter and unfavourable weather patterns (for home retailing). We do not anticipate any major market share performance issues. Official consumer confidence measures for big ticket purchases have remained solid.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

We do like the company long term, given market share dominance and cash-generative characteristics. We do not anticipate a dividend cut so the shares, at c.200p, now yield c.5.5%, with the prospect of additional payouts once trading stabilises. We will need to revisit our target price however.

With recent government data highlighting the pressure on real disposable incomes (inflation 2.7%, earnings 2.1%), it is undoubtedly a challenging time for retailers and there is a negative share price read-across for the sector from DFS today. Towards the end of the year we expect inflation to peak and the headwind to ease thereafter but there are undoubtedly choppy waters to navigate over the next six months.

BE11:27am

(Bloody hell, @Soundbuy.)

BE11:28am

And Clive Black at Shore.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Theresa May’s ‘strong & stable’ mantra would appear to quite wide of the mark
compared to where the UK consumer economy may be today. If care is not taken, it
instability could also be where it is heading on a more prolonged basis, so hitting
consumer sentiment and behaviour. Some stocks will be marked down heavily today,
DFS for sure, but investors in the larger ticket UK discretionary retail sector will be
twitchy, as are we, on this surprise announcement so soon after the General Election.

BE11:29am

Now, one swallow and a summer come to mind with this DFS update and we will naturally be alive to wider rather than company specific issues. However, if DFS is correct in its analysis then there would appear to be the greater likelihood of more short-term warnings coming from the non-food bricks & mortar retailers in the UK in the near-term, particularly the bigger ticket discretionary players.
Today’s warning could, therefore, lead to a broader sell-off in the listed higher ticket UK general retailers over the next few days. Beyond the current hiatus, if that is the case, the dust may quickly settle. Whilst so, we do harbour a concern that Theresa May’s ill-fated General Election may have slightly more enduring implications for UK consumer confidence and, indeed, business confidence, both domestic and importantly with respect to ongoing foreign direct investment (FDI). Time will tell, hopefully, our growing caution is misplaced but we are materially more worried about the UK consumer economy post GE2017.

Kingfisher PLC (KGF:LSE): Last: 300.40, down 9.9 (-3.19%), High: 306.00, Low: 300.00, Volume: 4.06m
11:30 am
Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 306.90, down 13.4 (-4.18%), High: 320.50, Low: 306.70, Volume: 1.65m
BE11:30am

Any other big ticket? None I can think of, though Dunelm's often chucked into this basket.

Dunelm Group PLC (DNLM:LSE): Last: 602.50, down 37.5 (-5.86%), High: 623.50, Low: 598.50, Volume: 275.58k
11:30 am
BE11:31am

Oh, and AO.

AO World PLC (AO.:LSE): Last: 124.30, down 4.7 (-3.64%), High: 127.30, Low: 122.90, Volume: 106.52k
BE11:31am

You get the idea.

11:31 am
undefined
BE11:31am

Still on retail, CS has picked a good day to turn negative on Next.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 4,074, down 227 (-5.28%), High: 4,217, Low: 4,068, Volume: 401.69k
11:32 am
BE11:32am

Similar themes. Weak demand, inflation coming through, etc.

BE11:33am

(@Flaneur: yep. DIY and, perhaps less intuitively, big telly sales correlate quite well with housing volumes.)

BE11:33am

Our June price survey shows that in the face of continued weak demand for apparel and increasing competition from online, that pricing remains soft across Europe, despite it being almost a year since the post Brexit weakness in sterling and two years since the main falls in the Euro/US$. The two most influential brands remain Primark, which comfortably retains its price advantage over peers, and Zara. While the price reductions of the past two years appear to be complete, the bunching of prices clearly shows the lack of pricing power in the face of higher US$ costs. ABF (PT 3,200p) and Zalando (PT €47.5) remain our only Outperforms in the apparel space, we reiterate our Underperform ratings for H&M (PT SKr200) and Inditex (PT €25), and are taking Next back to Underperform (from N) with a 12m FWD target price of 4,000p (vs 4,250p).

11:03 am
BE11:03am

Picture.

BE11:36am

The pricing survey's kinda fascinating in its own right.

BE11:36am

11:36 am
BE11:36am

So that's "the average price of an upper range and lower range, comprising two cheapest and most expensive SKU's in 9 different product categories"

BE11:36am

36 price points per brand per country

BE11:37am

What's with the bunching? Why's that happened?

11:37 am
undefined
BE11:38am

And to Howden, since it's mentioned a lot.

Howden Joinery Group PLC (HWDN:LSE): Last: 426.60, down 27.7 (-6.10%), High: 445.00, Low: 419.30, Volume: 4.16m
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Again, DFS warning. Big ticket / property spending readthrough.

BE11:40am

Though you'll note that not only have the housebuilder numbers been good (which is of limited readthrough due to an artificial market, for all the reasons we talk about endlessly) but Severfield wasn't bad yesterday.

BE11:41am

Anyway, all sector. Just sector.

11:41 am
undefined
BE11:42am

Who mentioned Petrofac?

Petrofac Ltd (PFC:LSE): Last: 439.28, up 34.18 (+8.44%), High: 443.00, Low: 412.50, Volume: 5.51m
11:42 am
BE11:42am

This is Jefferies knife catching.

BE11:42am

Quantifying the SFO investigation may well be a fool's game

BE11:43am

... it says in a note upgrading to "buy".

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Which is one approach, I guess.

BE11:43am

But Petrofac has some
blue-chip FTSE100 peers to give us a steer that investigations "usually" last multiple years
before the quantum of a fine comes into view. We introduce a $200m fine but only in 2019.
We also, given the fall in the stock, suspend the dividend from our estimates which provides
for ~$225m p.a. cash outflow savings.

BE11:43am

The concern for us ahead of this was, and is, E&C awards: With the wind-down
of the IES business, Petrofac is more than ever dependent on its Lump-sum E&C business.
Following the announcement of ~$2bn E&C awards so far this year we reduce our revenue
estimates for this division (again) but at the same time we "only" look for $3bn E&C
awards in total during 2017 to meet our revised revenue estimates which does give the
company a viable awards target and indeed the rest of the year to show that recent, post-
SFO, announcements of RCF credit facility extension by 1yr to 2021 and the 5yr training
agreement contract in Kuwait are in fact true evidence that business can continue near
normal.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Working Capital, Working Capital, Working Capital: Is a question we get asked
nearly every day and we try in this note to both discover the acute concern and address
the issue. For a stock trading at 3x EV/EBITDA and 5-6x PER it seems to us that the dividend
should be considered for internal uses. Suspending it provides $665m cumulative FCF 2017
- 2020 vs $977m of debt maturities and finance lease commitments over that time. Partial
repayment and/or refinancing are an option with our estimates materially below ND/EBITDA
covenants (less than 3x).

BE11:44am

Valuation/Risks
500p/sh PT (down from 835p/sh). Upgrade to Buy (from Hold). Average of three
methodologies and no dividend. Highest: EV/EBITDA of 680p on 5.3x (5yr ave FY/FY+1
multiple minus -std dev) and ave FY17/18 EBITDA of $656m. Lowest: DCF 288p using 11%
WACC (1% terminal growth). Mid-case valuation 545p/sh uses 8.2x (5yr ave -1std dev) to
FY17/18e ave. EPS of 83cts / $286m.

BE11:45am

The shadow being cast over any precedent, with relation to the SFO, is that the agency is still mortally threatened by our current government (such as it is).

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Anyway, that's that.

undefined
BE11:46am

Elsewhere in sellside.

11:46 am
ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 181.37, down 3.43 (-1.86%), High: 184.00, Low: 181.10, Volume: 4.64m
BE11:47am

Maquarie cautious on free to air generally and the UK specifically.

BE11:47am

It's part of a big, wandering media note that's largely top down.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

(@wayneJ: I'm ignoring it for the moment, in the manner of a supply teacher who keeps writing on the blackboard for five seconds after the paper aeroplane hits his head.)

BE11:49am

Maquarie's all "moving into the mid-cycle slowing phase, we expect a duration of ~13 months, with the US hitting an inflection point slightly faster than what the OECD LI would suggest."

BE11:49am

I'll spare you that stuff, which is a bit chewy, and go straight to ITV.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

As part of the move to underweight free-to-air broadcasters, we are downgrading the shares of ITV to Neutral from Outperform. Valuation looks attractive, and ITV remains a credible takeover target, but we believe wandering British politics will inevitably affect advertising spending in 2017/18.

BE11:49am

The increasing political uncertainty in the UK (eg, soft/hard Brexit, May’s minority government) is starting to affect business confidence, which has been at an all-time high, while consumer confidence declined in the run-up to the June elections (see chart below). A weakening sterling, which boosted exporters’ optimism, now seems to be affecting consumer spending (Visa reported a 1% decline in May – the first decline in four years). In short, the balance of risk has sharply moved to the downside for advertising spending.

undefined
11:51 am
BE11:52am

@leckford mentioned hotels earlier.

BE11:52am

Which is convenient, because it's an excuse to mention InterContinental.

InterContinental Hotels Group PLC (IHG:LSE): Last: 4,333, down 76.35 (-1.73%), High: 4,346, Low: 4,316, Volume: 195.40k
11:52 am
BE11:53am

Morgan Stanley -- generally very good on the leisure sector -- does a load of work on pipelines

BE11:53am

And decides that IHG's isn't all that.

BE11:53am

The hotel cycle drives 80% of the sector's share price performance in the long run, so RevPAR is the key determinant. However, this is mostly a macro call, and individual stock performance can vary enormously. One driver is expansion, particularly for asset light hoteliers whose high margins make them less geared to RevPAR. We have analysed hotel pipelines to assess potential revenue growth from new space. Rooms growth ≠ revenue growth. While the 3 companies have similar pipelines at 25-30% of current size, IHG's is opening at a slower pace, has a more negative mix to lower RevPAR markets, and a higher rate of hotel removals. Its relatively disappointing net rooms growth of c. 3% in the last 2 years is well known; less well understood is that sales growth from new space is running at c. two-thirds of this (we estimate 2.2% in 2016, vs asset light peers at 5-7%).

11:53 am
BE11:54am

IHG trades on a similar multiple to its asset light peers (13.5x EV/EBITDA, 21.6x P/E, 4.3% FCF yield FY18e), but is seeing weaker RevPAR and weaker space growth, suggesting the shares will underperform, with a 1x derating 8% to the share price. Separately, we increase FY17e/18e EPS by 1-4% as we now assume no further slowdown in US RevPAR, and this plus higher group multiples leads to our new £43 PT. Accor remains a top pick, Overweight. We estimate c. 5% sales growth from new space with a neutral mix effect and low removals. Accor is enjoying the strongest RevPAR growth (we upgraded forecasts here), we see a positive catalyst from it exiting 'B ooster' and going asset light, and it has an attractive valuation (12x FY18e EV/EBITDA, 17x P/E, assuming a €6.0bn GAV for 'B ooster').

BE11:55am

Who was it that was arguing the other day that Premier Inn's looking a bit overextended?

BE11:55am

Cenkos. That was it.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

https://www.ft.com...-919a-1e14ce4af89b

BE11:55am

Suggestion here is that Premier Inn is reluctant to go through £200 a night, which keeps a lid on its revpar.

BE11:56am

And competitors are sharpening up at around that price. Z Hotels, for instance, looks a decent operator.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Anyway, Morgan Stanley doesn't entirely agree.

BE11:57am

Whitbread should see the strongest space growth. Whitbread’s Premier Inn is generating a superior c. 8% sales growth from new space, so even though its business model is currently not in vogue (single brand market, owned leased), this is a powerful growth story, and yet it trades on by far the lowest valuation (8.7x cal '18e EV/EBITDA). To sceptics, we note PI's returns have been stable and high, and its superior hotel occupancy (81%) suggests plenty of opportunity.

Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 3,956, down 71 (-1.76%), High: 4,023, Low: 3,953, Volume: 116.56k
11:57 am
undefined
BE11:58am

Only two risers FTSE100 now.

BE11:59am

I'd check US futures but can't currently find them on my Reuters box.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Instead, have another broker who's been fortunate enough to put out a sell call on a down day.

BE11:59am

Goldman this time.

International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 588.00, down 16.5 (-2.73%), High: 600.50, Low: 587.00, Volume: 7.50m
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Positive Ryanair, neutral "BA owner", negative Luft.

BE12:01pm

Flag carriers have outperformed LCCs ytd (65% vs. 29%), benefitting from the cyclical recovery in long-haul pricing. We believe the next leg of airline performance will be driven by structural trends: (1) potential capacity exits from financially challenged airlines and (2) Ryanair accelerating growth in Germany. Hence, we shift our preference to LCCs, which we expect to be the main beneficiaries of consolidation and improving short-haul supply- demand.

BE12:01pm

Alitalia’s administration process and the emerging financial challenges facing Air Berlin suggest marginal players continue to suffer from increasing LCC competition, despite the lower oil price. While we take no view on the Alitalia situation, our analysis suggests potential short-haul capacity cuts by Alitalia could present a revenue opportunity of up to €1.4bn, depending on the scenario (based on its FY16 revenues and its 50% share of short-haul capacity, as per OAG); we believe Ryanair would benefit the most from this.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Our analysis suggests that short-haul capacity growth will slow to 5.4% yoy in August (vs. 7% in 1H17). We expect financially challenged carriers to cut capacity further, which could bring supply-demand more into balance in 2018. As a result, we upgrade our industry pricing expectations and raise our 2017-18 EBITDA by 8%, on average. We are now an average 6% above Bloomberg consensus on LCC 2018 EBITDA.

BE12:01pm

We see RYA and Wizz as the main beneficiaries of potential legacy carrier exits. We upgrade RYA to Buy from Neutral, with 21% upside to our new 12m price target of €22.0. RYA trades at 12.7x 2018E P/E vs. its 13.5x 10-year historical average, while generating a 17% EPS CAGR (CY18-20E). We reiterate our Buy on Wizz (new 12m PT of 2,750p) but remove it from the CEEMEA Focus List, following outperformance ytd. We lower IAG to Neutral from Buy, following performance (our new 12m PT of 645p implies 7% upside). We retain our Sell on Lufthansa (our new 12m PT of €13.62 implies 28% downside).

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 18.25, down 0.05 (-0.27%), High: 18.60, Low: 18.13, Volume: 677.07k
12:01 pm
undefined
BE12:02pm

Oh yeah, the BOE.

BE12:02pm

Still 0.25%, vote 5-3

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

That's three for a hike, obv.

BE12:03pm

Sterling popped a bit on that.

BE12:03pm

Currently about $1.2775 in the middle.

12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

FTSE now down 1.1%.

BE12:04pm

BE11:34am

Next: the price survey would seem to suggest that Next has cut entry level pricing during S/S, possibly in response to the very poor 1Q sales (Retail - 8.1%, Directory +3.3%). We continue to believe that its strategy of expanding UK space is incorrect for a mature retailer and that self-help from Credit, International and Label will diminish, and potentially reverse, over the next two years. With earnings, margins and cash conversion continuing to fall we regard Next as a value trap.
